rsbNotes.title: Acts 24:1
rsbNotes.text: 24:1 Tertullus. As an orator, Tertullus was a kind of lawyer, possibly a Jew (he refers to Jewish law as “our” law, v. 6, text note).

rsbNotes.title: Acts 24:5–7
rsbNotes.text: 24:5–7 Tertullus charged that Paul was a chronic troublemaker, the leader of a disreputable religious sect, and a person who threatened to profane the temple. Paul replied to these accusations in his defense before Felix (vv. 10–21).

rsbNotes.title: Acts 24:5
rsbNotes.text: 24:5 the Nazarenes. Christians were identified as followers of Jesus of Nazareth. “Nazareth” may have been a term of contempt (John 1:46).

rsbNotes.title: Acts 24:14
rsbNotes.text: 24:14 I worship . . . God. Paul assured Felix that as a Jew he followed a religion protected by Rome. As a follower of “the Way,” Paul worshiped the “God of our fathers” and believed in the resurrection of the dead (Dan. 12:1, 2; 1 Thess. 4:13–18; 2 Thess. 1:8).

rsbNotes.title: Acts 24:21
rsbNotes.text: 24:21 the resurrection of the dead. Paul made one critical statement that pertained not to Roman political interests but to Jewish and Christian theology.

rsbNotes.title: Acts 24:23
rsbNotes.text: 24:23 he should be kept . . . liberty. As a Roman citizen whose case was still pending, Paul was given some freedom (28:16).

rsbNotes.title: Acts 24:24
rsbNotes.text: 24:24 Drusilla. Daughter of Herod Agrippa I (12:1–23) and sister of Herod Agrippa II (25:13; 26:3 note) and Bernice (25:13 note), Drusilla left Azizus, king of Emesa in Syria, to marry Felix. She probably died along with her son Agrippa in the eruption of Mt. Vesuvius at Pompeii, a.d. 79.

rsbNotes.title: Acts 24:27
rsbNotes.text: 24:27 Porcius Festus. Festus was from a noble family in Rome. Though Felix had been greedy and evil, Festus was wise and honorable.
